Award.AwardTitle: Preservice Teachers Knowledge for Teaching Algebra for Equity in the Middle Grades

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research study enriches the education of STEM teachers by using emergent technology to provide pre-service middle school mathematics teachers early teaching experiences that address topics in algebra and equity. In particular, the research team at Texas A&M University Main Campus is using Second Life and other technology to structure carefully planned learning experiences for pre-service teachers. Virtual technologies are used to provide pre-service teachers practice in presenting and assessing problem solving activities in a virtual classroom with diverse populations. Researchers hypothesize that technology enriched strategies have the potential to deepen pre-service teachers' understanding and effectiveness in teaching emerging algebra concepts to diverse student populations. The activities of the study are designed to answer five research questions:
1. How successful are the proposed design strategies for developing technology-rich activities for pre-service teachers?
2. How effective are technology-rich activities in developing pre-service teachers' deep knowledge and understanding of the algebra concepts of variable, change, and operations?
3. How effective are virtual simulations of problem-based teaching of algebra concepts in enhancing pre-service teachers' knowledge and skill in teaching diverse students?
4. What are the trajectories of pre-service teachers' development of knowledge of teaching algebra concepts to diverse students?
5. To what extent can technology-rich activities be effectively implemented in a whole-class setting?

The study is a design experiment using an iterative process to develop prototypes that pre-service teachers employ to become more effective in teaching algebra concepts to diverse student populations. Up to 25 students in a semester are piloting the materials that are continually being refined based on the results of the piloting. Growth in knowledge and practice by students is being measured by assessment instruments and research observations. The Mathematics Teacher Efficacy and Beliefs Instrument is an existing measure. The Knowledge for Teaching Algebra for Equity (KTAE) test is being developed to use as a pre- and posttest in the final phase of the project when students in sections who use and do not use the prototypes are compared. One hundred students are field testing the KTAE. The five member advisory board is being used for guidance and evaluation.

Products from the study will include prototype problem solving and equity activities, a knowledge for teaching algebra for equity (KTAE) assessment, guide to simulation of mathematics students in Second Life, and trajectories of knowledge for teaching algebra for equity. Findings from the study are being disseminated through journals and at professional conferences. This project capitalizes upon the use of state-of-the-art technology to simulate dynamic classroom experiences beyond the scope of prior teacher training programs. Successful implementation could revolutionize teacher training on a broad scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Preservice Teachers Knowledge for Teaching Algebra for Equity in the Middle Grade project was a 5-year study design experiment using an iterative process to develop activities for pre-service teachers to become more effective in teaching algebra concepts to diverse student populations.  The activities of the study were designed to answer five research questions:

1. How successful are the proposed design strategies for developing technology-rich activities for pre-service teachers?

2. How effective are technology-rich activities in developing pre-service teachers' deep knowledge and understanding of the algebra concepts of variable, change, and operations?

3. How effective are virtual simulations of problem-based teaching of algebra concepts in enhancing pre-service teachers' knowledge and skill in teaching diverse students?

4. What are the trajectories of pre-service teachers' development of knowledge of teaching algebra concepts to diverse students?

5. To what extent can technology-rich activities be effectively implemented in a whole-class setting?

The primary purpose of the study was to enrich the education of pre-service teachers by using emergent technology to provide awareness and early simulated teaching experiences that address topics in algebra and equity. In particular, the research team at Texas A&M University employed Second Life and other technologies to structure carefully planned learning experiences for pre-service teachers. The learning experiences were developed and presented in a required problem solving course. As shown in Figure 1, the course activities included: (1) Mathematics Problem and Equity Challenges, (2) Discussions and Readings on Diversity, (3) Second Life (SL) Tutoring, and (4) Second Life (SL) Teaching.  

Figure 1. Problem Solving Course Activities for Teaching Algebra for Equity.

Products from the study included: (1) Seven problem solving and equity activities, (2) A classroom and other learning spaces in Second Life (see Figure 2), (3) Instructional materials to guide participants in implementing simulated teaching experiences in Second Life, (4) Hypothetical Learning Trajectories of knowledge for teaching algebra for equity, (5) An instrument to assess pre-service teachers’ knowledge for algebra teaching algebra for equity (KATE), and (6) A Virtual Classroom Observation Instrument (VCOI) to assess teaching in Second Life or other virtual environments.  

Figure 2. Second Life Classroom.

Findings from the study were disseminated through 6 journal articles, 6 book chapters, 6 refereed proceedings, and presentations at 30 national or international, and 16 regional or local professional conferences. We have found some potentially important information about the nature of pre-service teachers' knowledge of teaching algebra, their cultural beliefs, and the connections between knowledge and beliefs that may impact effectiveness in teaching diverse students.  For example:

  • The activities developed and implemented in the course provided a reasonably effective combination of approaches that help improve preservice middle grade math teachers’ knowledge and beliefs about teaching for equity. The activities designed to develop experiences with teaching diverse students helped participants to become more confident, armed with the knowledge and practice they gained, without sacrificing learning about math content and problem solving strategies.
  • Cultural beliefs have an important role in the participants’ ideas about interacting with students and answering their classroom questions. Participants showed a naïve acceptance of meritocracy in which students either have the needed assets to achieve or they have deficits that preclude them from achieving. This belief places the responsibility solely on the merit of the individual student and that student’s family, allowing the teacher to avoid the struggle of confronting social inequities such as race.
  • We have broken new ground in using virtual classrooms, such as Second Life, to simulate and develop early teaching knowledge and skills. Although we are continuing to develop the simulation of diversity and how that plays a role, we have been able to make the virtual classroom authentic enough to give pre-service teachers a sense of "being there" and interacting with students.
  • We have begun to understand which activities are effective in promoting and developing pre-service teachers' awareness and knowledge of teaching algebra for equity. For example, readings and classroom discussions of diversity, as well as Second Life activities have significant effects on diversity preparedness.
  • Helping students with misconceptions was a central intermediary between cultural beliefs and equitable algebra teaching. We believe this is a result not previously found in the literature, confirming our notion that teachers’ knowledge about helping students’ with misconceptions is important in teaching algebra for equity.
  • The pre-service teachers did not pay enough attention to mathematical concepts in their simulated teaching, either in lesson plans or simulated teaching activities. They spent a good amount of time on procedural knowledge, but with little connection to corresponding conceptual knowledge.
